reviewText: I viewed this movie many years ago when it was on VHS, and it struck me as one of the most realistic, honest, brutal portrayals of homeless youth I have seen at that time. Since watching it again, I have realized that things for our youths have gotten even worse and it frightens me. I keep it in my collection and watch it to remind myself to be grateful for things other people take for granted.

reviewText: This movie is ok if you want to see the grungy side of street life so I got what I ordered but more than I wanted to see.  The movie is what it says it is.  I just did not like it.
Title: N/A

reviewText: There is a superficiality to this movie that is a bit disconcerting.  I suppose it is ironic that big time actors (many not so big then) play no name children of the street.  It raises awareness, yes, but it also makes it look kind of cool.I lived in Seattle for a while and the young people living on the street have a certain belief in the 'coolness' of their lifestyle that actually validates this movie to a degree.Having worked with the homeless in my hometown, I've learned that it is not monolithic.  There are as many 'types' of homeless people as there are homeless people.  Does that make me an expert?  No.However, that being said, this is an excellent movie.  The cast is phenomenal.  With a score by Melissa Etheridge, the movie feels in places like a rock video but it also helps with the flow and mood.The movie does a good job of exposing, to a greater or lesser degree, the problems that leads to and come with being on the street.  It ain't pretty and the movie never really leads you to that conclusion.  While it certainly isn't graphic in an extreme sense, it does give you just enough to feel.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This movie sort of feels like an afterschool special regarding the horrors of running away from home, but has an awesome cast, i found the melissa ethridge heavy soundtrack to work really well, and i love seeing what LA (where I live) was like 20 years ago. That just made me feel really old because I first saw this when it came out and I dreamt of moving to LA

reviewText: A group of teen-age runaways try to survive in the streets of Los Angeles. Drugs, prostitution, violence and bureaucratic indifference all pose threats to the kids, who nevertheless prefer this harsh life to going back to their families. Heather, somewhat older, provides some leadership and mothering to the kids......Very "1992"-ish!!! Very dated!!!
summary: it's an ok movie, but a little dated.......

reviewText: Very basic video transfer on this DVD, to preserve the 16x9 framing, but the quality of the picture is not that great, and up-converting to does nothing to it as it has nothing to up-convert. Having said that, it actually looks OK and kind of works with the grime and grit of the story and the characters, that the image is not-so crystal clear as you might see on Blu-Ray. Still, what a great movie. This set the tone and feel for Hollywood's streets for the 90's.
summary: Always loved this movie, the DVD is so-so.

reviewText: This is a great movie that is unfortunately unknown to most people.  I guarantee all doubters will be pleasantly surprised, I was.  It is such an all around good film that you really need to put it under a microscope to criticize it.  But don't take my word for it, watch it yourself and Im sure you will agree with me.  There are not many movies that I deem are worth repeated viewings, but this is one of them. BRAVO to all involved!!

reviewText: Where the Day Takes You is a hard-to-find early look at an ensemble that plays against typecasting of their more cheerful and optimistic earlier and subsequent performances. In fact, the main players seemed to thrive on the opportunity to explore the gritty underbelly of early 90s Los Angeles.Laura San Giacomo's social worker/documentarian interviews of Dermot Mulroney's King bookend and frame this tale of homeless and hopeless youth and also structure the day-to-day ramblings and wanderings of King's "family" with structure.Mulroney as King plays tough-but-caring leader of the pack who introduces the audience to the people and places important in several days of his life.Most astonishing, is Ricki Lake as an urban tough girl, worlds away from bubbly Tracy Turnblad and talk show host. Lake dominates over her costars with such authenticity and authority, one wonders what would the day would have brought if she'd gone into feature films rather than daytime talk.Will Smith's charisma consistent with his family-friendly Fresh Prince image still shines through as a foul-mouthed spare change hustler with limited scenes and unresolved storyline.Sean Astin moves 180 degrees from never-say-die Rudy and Samwise Gamgee to a downward slope into darkness of escalating drug addiction.Kyle Maclaclan is not heroic Paul Atredis or wide-eyed wonder boy of Blue Velvet. Here, he is a full participant in the loathesome art of destroying lives as a pushy drug pusher.Lara Flynn Boyle joins the pack of outsiders as a sweet newcomer from the Midwest. In later roles she moves on to femme fatale portrayals such as the alien villainess opposite Will Smith in Men in Black.Where the Day Takes You focuses on characters in order to maintain viewer focus on the lives of the least of these. Excellent work by the cast.
summary: A young ensemble playing against type
Title: N/A

reviewText: Where The Day Takes You gives the viewer a look into the lives of young homeless people in Los Angeles.  Remarkable performances keep this film from being another After School Special type film.  Sean Astin is particularily effective in this movie, though I could have done without Will Smith and Ricki Lake.  Other than that, this film is a must see.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Dermot Mulroney (Wedding Date, Young Guns) plays King, who gets out of lock up and is back on the streets living under bridges and finding out his girlfriend has been playing around. He meets a girl named Heather, played by Lara Flynn Boyle (Happiness, Since You've Been Gone) and he shows her the ropes. He also goes to interview sessions as part of community service and is interviewed throughout the movie by the interviewer, played by Laura San Giacomo (sex, lies and videotape, The Stand). The cast include Sean Astin (Lord of The Rings, Smile) who plays a junkie, Will Smith (Jersey Girl, Men in Black) who is a cripple in a wheelchair, Ricki Lake (Mrs. Winterbourne) as Boyle's friend, Stephen Tobolowsky (Blue Streak, Black Dog), Kyle MacLachlan (Twin Peaks, One Night Stand), David Arquette (Scream, Riding the Bullet), Alyssa Milano (Buying the Cow, Charmed), Adam Baldwin (Serenity, Gacy), Rachel Ticotin (Con Air), James Le Gros (Near Dark, Ally McBeal), Peter Dobson (The Frighteners) and Balathazar Getty (Tv's Alias, Young Guns 2). Christian Slater (Heathers, Pump Up The Volume) contributes an unbilled cameo. Has some good really extreme things it in, the cast is good but not always there and if you want to see Sean Astin face down in vomit, well this is the movie for ya. Mulroney keeps this at bay giving a perfect performance.
summary: Dermot Mulroney scores perfection in Where The Day Takes You

reviewText: This  movie made so much of an impression on my older daughter a few years ago that she wanted our youngest to see  it. Teens who have the impression that a big city and freedom from parents, school, etc. is an easy path to happiness and success are shown the harsh reality of life on the street.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Dermot Mulroney is King, the leader of a group of L.A. street kids and runaways. As a part of his parole he answers questions about his life on the streets posed by Laura San Giacomo (not annoying at all). The kids and they are all kids this is a movie made when they were all so young, toss in Lara Flynn Boyle, Will smith in a wheel chair, Balthezar Getty and Sean Astin and this is a fine cast with a riveting, if not somewhat predictable story. the performances are all powerful and that pulls it through. Scathing indictment on throw away kids. Loved it and the performances.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was quite an impressive movie that held my interest from beginning to end.  The entire cast did a worthy job.  Where the Day Takes You addressed issues like homelessness and drug use.  I actually give this film 3.5  stars.  A better-than-good movie.

reviewText: A cast of actors who went on to fame-Will Smith, Balthazer Getty, Sean Astin, Ricki Lake, and Kyle MacLachlan, and more. It was actually filmed along Hollywood Boulevard and to places where the runaways lived, under a bridge over the Hollywood Freeway. If you have even been to Hollywood, you will love this movie for the nostalgia. They even meet in a small restaurant, hamburger joint, that is no longer there. It was a well directed film and it took me a long time to remember the title. But, I did and bought it on Amazon.
summary: An almost true story of runaways in Hollywood.
Title: N/A

reviewText: What I liked best about this movie was Kyle Maclachlan shooting heroin between his toes, later tossing one of the main characters dead of an overdose (which he'd obtained from Maclachlan's character) into a dumpster. Not the most optimistic of tales, this one is more a reality scenario study. Not bad.
